text: 30 THE HISTORY book storm gathering in Germany, and where it would burst he could not foresee. Of Vi- tellius and his designs no certain account arrived. The revolt of the legions filled him with apprehensions, and he reposed no confidence in the praetorian guards. The nomination of a successor seemed, in such a crisis, to be the best expedient; and for that purpose he held a cabinet council. Besides Vinius and Laco, he thought proper to summon Marius Celsus^ consul elect, and Ducennius Geminus, the praefect of the city. Having prefaced the business in a short speech concerning his age and infirmities, he sent for Piso Lici- nianus (a); whether of his own free choice, or at the instigation of Laco, remains uncertain. That minister had lived in friendship with Piso. He contracted an intimacy with him at the house of Rubel- lius Plautus, though he had now the ad- dress to conceal that connection, affecting, with public/motives, to recommend a stranger.
